State Key Laboratory of Electroanalytical Chemistry, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Changchun 130022 China The synthesis of 1,6–hexamethylenediamine via the reductive amination of 1,6–hexanediol is a fascinating green process and a challenging topic. We developed a kind of Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 catalyst for the reductive amination of 1,6–hexanediol, the active Ru species was highly dispersed and anchored by the CNx species formed from 1,10-phenanthroline (PRL). The Ru particle dispersion, electronic interaction, and acid–basic property as well as the catalytic mechanism and the rate determining step were discussed in detail. The new and more acid–base pairs formed, and the electron deficient Ru species and smaller nanoparticles are responsible for the improved catalytic performances of Ru/PRL–Al2O3 catalyst. The yield of 1,6–hexamethylenediamine could reach to 54%, which is the best results reported up to now. The present catalytic process is of great potential for industrial application as it is a green process compared to the traditional method for 1,6–hexamethylenediamine production. Graphical Abstract Ru/PRL–Al2O3 catalyst was efficient for production of 1,6-hexamethylenediamine from a green route of 1,6-hexanediol reductive amination, which benefited from the high Ru dispersion, electron deficient Ru species and the adequate surface acid-base pairs. ga1 Keywords 1,6–hexamethylenediamine 1,6–hexanediol Reductive amination 1,10-phenanthroline Carbon nitride Ru/Al2O3 Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Amines are major chemicals in the industrial production of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, polymers and dyes [1]. In particular, primary amines are the most useful intermediates for further derivatization reaction [2]. One of the most significant amines is the primary diamine such as 1,6–hexamethylenediamine (HMDA) [3,4], its production is about 2 million tons per year over the world and mainly used in the production of nylon–6,6 and nylon–6,10 [5]. HMDA is mainly produced from the hydrogenation of adiponitrile in ammonia over cobalt or iron catalysts [6]. However, the production of adiponitrile usually involves a hypertoxic hydrocyanic acid used in the hydrocyanation of butadiene, hence it is of great demand to develop a green and environmentally friendly method for production of HMDA to replace the traditional hydrocyanation method. Nowadays, a single–step conversion of abundant alcohols or aldehydes into primary amines using NH3 as nitrogen source has attracted much attention and some progresses have been obtained [1–3,7,8]. Direct one–pot amination of alcohol is a safe and environmentally benign process as water was the sole byproduct [8]. What’s more, 1,6–hexanediol (HDO) can be obtained from biomass through hydrogenolysis of 5–(hydroxymethyl) furfural and tetrahydrofuran–2,5–dimethanol as reported [9,10]. As a result, to produce HMDA directly from the reductive amination of HDO with NH3/H2 is a quite green and promising route, which has attracted much attention. The direct reductive amination of alcohol usually operates via the so–called “Hydrogen Borrowing” mechanism relying on the concomitant dehydrogenation and hydrogenation reactions [11]. Up to now, the most advanced hydrogen–borrowing catalysts reported are homogeneous Ru and Ir complexes [12–15]. While the heterogeneous catalysts such as Ru [16,17], Ni [18,19] and Co [20,21] supported over alkaline or amphoteric oxides were also studied as their easy separation and recyclability as well as relatively low cost compared to the homogeneous ones. Ordomsky et al. reported that Ru/TiO2 was active in catalyzing the reductive amination of 1-octanol and the particle size of Ru largely affected the 1-octylamine yield; the better yield presented on the catalyst with smaller Ru particles [22]. Recently, it was reported that 1-octanol amination with NH3 over Ru nanoparticles was a structure-insensitive reaction while the oligomerization of primary amine (1-octylamine) was structure-sensitive [23]. Owing to the steric constraints, the primary amine was produced selectively as its self-coupling was prohibited on the smaller Ru particles. The similar result was also reported over Bi or carbon modified Co/γ-Al2O3 and Ni3P/Al2O3 catalysts [24–26]. Han et al. reported that N dopant could enhance the catalytic selectivity of Ru/N-CNT in the reductive amination of lactic acid to alanine due to the improved dispersion and the strong electronic interaction between N dopant and the Ru nanoparticles [27]. Besides, the properties of support such as the acidity and basicity also influenced the catalytic activity in the reductive amination [17]. Fang et al. prepared a series of zeolite supported Ru catalysts and found that 5 wt% Ru/HBEA (Si/Al, 25) gave a high yield (90%) of 1-octylamine at a high conversion (>90%) in the direct amination reaction of 1-octanol with ammonia at 180 °C, which was attributed to the presence of medium strength Brønsted-/Lewis-acid sites in the proximity of Ru nanoparticles [17]. The metal sites and the Lewis acid–base pair sites at the interface of metal and support played crucial role in the activation of hydroxyl and adsorption of intermediates in the reductive amination of alcohols [18,19,28–30]. The amination of monobasic alcohols is a quite complex process and difficult to produce primary amines with high selectivity due to its higher nucleophilicity compared to NH3 [18,23–28,30]. Moreover, it is much more difficult to produce primary diamines from reductive amination of diols because the bifunctional groups of diols lead to more side reactions such as oligomerization and cyclization. Thus, the reductive amination of diols is more challenging due to the desired primary diamine is difficult to obtain [6,15,31–37]. As for the reductive amination of HDO over the heterogeneous catalysts, the initial results were reported in patents over Co–Cu and Raney Ni catalysts with a quite lower yield of HMDA (< 40%) [33,38–41]. Recently, Zhao et al. reported Co/γ–Al2O3 was effective for the reductive amination of HDO, the conversion of hydroxyl groups is about 90%, but the selectivity to HMDA was not given [42]. Luo et al. reported hydrotalcite–derived NiCu/MgAlO could catalyze the reductive amination of HDO, a 20.0% selectivity to HMDA was obtained at a conversion of 77% [43]. Rose et al. reported Ru/C benchmark catalyst gave a conversion up to 79% in the reductive amination of HDO, but neither the yield nor the selectivity to HMDA was given [44]. More recently, the same research group reported that the addition of Ba(OH)2 could significantly improve the catalytic activity and selectivity of Ru/C catalyst, in which the yield of HMDA reached 34% at a nearly complete conversion [45]. Besides, we found that Ru/Al2O3 was effective and gave a 38% yield of HMDA [34]. Herein, the purpose of our present work is to further improve the selectivity of HMDA in the reductive amination of HDO through designing an efficient catalyst with high Ru dispersion and appropriate acid–basic properties. As the primary amine self–coupling is a structure–sensitive reaction, adjusting the Ru particle size could improve the formation of primary amine [23,24]. Therefore, a kind of Ru/Al2O3 catalyst with highly dispersed Ru particle (< 1 nm) was prepared by modification with 1,10–phenanthroline (PRL), on which carbon nitride (CN x ) was formed on the surface of catalyst during the high temperature calcination, which can anchor Ru particle to smaller in size. The small Ru particle and the suitable acidity–basicity favor for HMDA production, as the formation of dimers and trimers was inhibited. The relationship between catalyst structure (Ru particle size, electronic interaction, acidity/basicity, etc.) and the catalytic performances (activity and selectivity) has been well discussed. The present catalytic process for synthesis of HMDA is of a great potential application as a green process to replace the traditional adiponitrile route. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials γ–Al2O3 (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, analytical purity) was used as support and Ruthenium (III) chloride n–hydrate (Sigma–Aldrich, 35–40% Ru) as metal precursor. 1,10–phenanthroline (PRL), phenanthrene, 2,2′-bipyridine, 1,8-naphthyridine, 2,6-bis(2-benzimidazolyl)pyridine was purchased from Yili Fine Chemicals (>99%), Acros (97%), Innochem (98%), Alfa Aesar (98%) and Innochem (98%), respectively. 1,6–hexanediol (HDO, 98%) and 1–pentylamine (PA, 98%) were purchased from Aladdin. 1,6–hexamethylenediamine (HMDA, 99%), hexamethyleneimine (HMI, 98%), 6–amino–1–hexanol (AHO, 97%), 1–pentanol (PO, 99%) and tert–butanol (>99%) was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry. All chemicals used in this work are of analytical grade and used without further purification. Gases of H2 (99.999%) was purchased from Changchun Juyang Gases Co., Ltd and NH3 (99.999%) was purchased from Dalian special Gases Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation As shown in Scheme 1, at first, a modified γ–Al2O3 hybrid support was prepared by thermal treatment of a mixture of Al2O3 and modifier of 1,10–phenanthroline (PRL). Al2O3 was firstly added into an ethanol solution of PRL, stirred at 60 °C for 6 h and then evaporated ethanol out at room temperature; subsequently dried at 80 °C in an oven overnight; finally, the dried sample was thermally treated at 800 °C in N2 atmosphere for 2 h (step 1), named PRL–Al2O3. The catalyst was prepared by impregnating the hybrid support PRL–Al2O3 with an ethanol solution of ruthenium (III) chloride n–hydrate at 60 °C stirring for 6 h, ethanol was evaporated at room temperature under continuous stirring, and the resultant solid was dried overnight at 80 °C. Subsequently, the sample was calcined at 400 °C in N2 atmosphere for 2 h (step 2). Before used in the reductive amination, the calcined sample was pre–reduced at 250 °C for 2 h in H2 flow (step 3). The loading of Ru is 3 wt%. The catalysts were named as Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3, in which x means the mole ratio of PRL/Ru (0.5, 1, 2, 4). For comparison, a series of Ru/Al2O3 catalysts modified with substance similar to PRL such as phenanthrene, 2,2′-bipyridine, 1,8-naphthyridine, 2,6-bis(2-benzimidazolyl)pyridine were also prepared by the same synthetic processes described above with a mole ratio of modifier/Ru being 1. 2.3 Characterization The actual Ru loading was determined by inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy (ICP–OES), the loading of Ru on all the catalysts is about 3 wt%. Powder X–ray diffraction (XRD) was performed to measure the crystal phases of the catalysts using a Bruker D8 Advance X–ray diffractometer with a Cu Kα source at 40 kV and 40 mA in a 2θ range from 10° to 90°. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained on a JEOL JEM–2010 instrument (Japan) operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on VG Microtech 3000 Multilab equipped with an Al Kα X–ray exciting source (1486.6 eV). The C1s peak at 284.6 eV was used as a reference for charge–up correction. Raman spectra were measured on a confocal laser micro–Raman spectrometer (Horiba Jobin Yvon LabRAM HR800) equipped with a diode laser of excitation of 325 nm. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2–TPR) was carried out in a flow of 10 vol% H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Both carbon dioxide temperature programmed desorption (CO2–TPD) and ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3–TPD) experiments were performed on a Tianjin XQ TP–5080 chemisorption instrument with a TCD. As for the CO2–TPD or NH3–TPD, 50 mg calcined sample was loaded into a quartz reactor and then reduced with a H2 flow (30 mL min−1) at 250 °C for 2 h. After cooling to room temperature in Ar flow (30 mL min−1), the reactor was exposed to a pure CO2 or NH3 flow (20 mL/min) for 30 min. After the adsorption, the reactor was flushed with helium and stayed at 100 °C for 30 min and then the reactor was cooled to room temperature. Until the baseline was stable, CO2–TPD or NH3–TPD was carried out with helium at a flow rate of 30 mL min−1 and a temperature ramp rate of 10 °C min−1. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption experiments were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and porosity analyzer. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve was recorded using a Perkin–Elmer Thermal Analysis from room temperature to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in an air flow. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of CO adsorption was performed on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. Around 30 mg of the sample was reduced in situ in a flowing 10% H2/Ar mixture (30 mL min−1) at 250 °C for 15 min. Then it was cooled to 30 °C in flowing helium at 30 mL min−1 and purged with flowing helium for another 15 min. After that, the background was recorded. The sample was exposed to a stream of 10% CO/helium at a flow rate of 30 mL min−1 for 30 min. The spectra were recorded once per minute while passing helium at 30 mL min−1. 2.4 Activity measurement In typical reductive amination, HDO (5 mmol), Ru/PRL(1)-Al2O3 (100 mg) and tert–butanol (5 mL) was loaded into a 100 mL stainless steel reactor. The reactor was flushed with N2 for three times. After being heated to 220 °C, the reactor was filled with 1 MPa of H2, and then ammonia was pumped into the reactor using a high-pressure pump to the desired pressure of 16 MPa. The reaction was conducted while the reaction mixture was stirred with a magnetic stirrer (800 r/min). After reaction, the reactor was cooled and depressurized carefully. The liquid mixture was analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC–2014 C) equipped with a capillary column (Rtx–50) and a flame ionization detector. The temperature of injection and detection were 285 and 320 °C, respectively, and hexadecane as the internal standard. The conversion was calculated by moles of HDO consumed divided by initial moles of HDO added and the selectivity was determined by moles of product i produced divided by moles of HDO consumed. The preparation of catalyst and the catalytic performances can be well reproduced with an error less than 2%, based on the conversion and selectivity calculated from GC analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performances For the amination of HDO, one hydroxyl of HDO underwent the dehydrogenation and then reacted with NH3 to form the corresponding imine, which subsequently went through hydrogenation and thus generated AHO. The other hydroxyl, afterwards, encountered the similar experience to form HMDA. Under the reaction conditions, several products such as HMI, dimers and trimers were also formed from cyclization and oligomerization due to the –NH2 group is more reactive than NH3 [19,46]. Some chain broken products of PO and PA will also be produced. At first, we prepared several Ru/Al2O3 catalysts modified with different modifiers, and their catalytic performances in the reductive amination of HDO were evaluated (Fig. S1). Among the samples examined the one modified by PRL showed the best catalytic performances in the reductive amination of HDO, both the catalytic activity and selectivity to HMDA was improved largely compared with the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst without any modification. It was supposed that a CN x layer was formed on the surface of Al2O3 in the thermal treatment as the sample of PRL-Al2O3 changed from white to black after heated in N2 at 800 °C. the same phenomenon also presented in the sample with modifier of 2,6-bis(2-benzimidazolyl)pyridine. The thermal treating temperature is crucial for carbonization and the carbonate species formation. As Fig. 1 shown, with raising thermal treatment temperature in the preparation of PRL-Al2O3, both the conversion and selectivity to HMDA increased and reached the highest values of 100% and 54% at 800 °C, respectively. But decreased to 72% and 20%, respectively, with further raising temperature to 900 °C, which could be ascribed to the decomposition and gasification of the surface CN x layer at the high temperature of 900 °C according to the color change from black to white at 900 °C. Besides, the calcination temperature of catalyst Ru/PRL-Al2O3 presented the similar effects. With increasing calcination temperature, the activity and selectivity to HMDA increased and reached the highest values at 400 °C then decreased (Fig. S2). Thus, in the following study, the thermal treatment temperature of support PRL-Al2O3 (step 1) was fixed at 800 °C and the calcination temperature of Ru/PRL-Al2O3 catalyst (step 2) was kept at 400 °C. The catalytic performances of Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 catalysts with different molar ratio of PRL/Ru were evaluated for the reductive amination of HDO, the results are shown in Fig. 2. The conversion reached above 95% on all the catalysts irrespective to the value of PRL/Ru under the reaction conditions, while the selectivities to AHO, HMDA and HMI were influenced largely. With the increase of PRL/Ru ratio, the amount of AHO decreased, the selectivity to HMDA and HMI increased firstly then decreased, but the selectivity to dimers and trimers presented a contrary result. The presence of PRL improved the selectivity to HMDA, the highest selectivity of 54% presented on Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3 at a PRL/Ru ratio of 1, which is much higher than the result (39%) obtained on the unmodified Ru/Al2O3, and it is superior to all the results over the heterogeneous catalysts reported up to now (Table S1). It is obvious that the presence of PRL could promote the formation of byproduct HMI, whose selectivity increased from 7% to 27% when the PRL/Ru increased from 0 to 2, the selectivity to dimers and trimers decreased. Thus, the change of product distribution with reaction time was examined by the catalysts containing different PRL/Ru ratios. As the present reaction contains several parallel and tandem reactions, the reaction duration selected was a little difference based on the forming rate of the desired product on different catalysts. Fig. 3 shows that AHO was formed as intermediate during the reaction and it was converted mainly to the desired product of HMDA, simultaneously a byproduct of HMI also formed and its selectivity increased with prolonging reaction time over all the catalysts examined. However, on the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst without PRL modification, much more coupling byproducts such as dimers and trimers were formed, while the coupling byproducts were less formed on the Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3 catalyst, indicating the oligomerization was reduced on the PRL modified catalysts. When AHO was near full consumption, the total selectivity to HMDA and HMI reached about 80% over both the Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3 and Ru/PRL(2)–Al2O3 catalysts. It’s worth noting that HMI is a kind of important substance with a widely application in the synthesis of herbicides like molinate [47], molecular sieves [48,49] and medical drugs [50]. Therefore, it is an attractive process for production of HMDA and HMI simultaneously. Based on the product selectivity changing with reaction time, the reductive amination of HDO should go through the pathway as list in Scheme 2. The PRL modification accelerated reaction rate largely especially for the first step of HDO transferring to AHO (from 0.12 to 0.23 mol·gRu −1 ·h−1), and inhibit the formation of dimers and trimers (Fig. 3). When AHO is used as reactant, the addition of PRL significantly promoted the reaction rate, and the reaction rate (based on the weight of Ru species used) was enhanced from 0.18 to 0.29 mol·gRu −1 ·h−1 (Table S2). Thus, the relation between the catalyst structure and catalytic performances was discussed by correlating the product selectivity, reaction rate with the surface structure and properties of catalysts. 3.2 Catalyst structure The interface and electronic structure of catalysts were characterized, as the results of TGA in Fig. 4 a, the PRL(1)–Al2O3 lost much more weight than Al2O3 in thermal treatment indicating the Al2O3 was successfully coated/modified by PRL. Furthermore, the coating or modifying species was confirmed by Raman spectra as shown in Fig. 4 b, there is no obvious band detected on the sample of Al2O3. Nevertheless, on the sample of PRL(1)–Al2O3, one peak located at 1350 cm–1 (D–band) corresponding to the disordered carbon and the other at 1590 cm–1 (G–band) corresponding to all pairs of sp2 atoms in both carbon rings and chains were observed, and the obvious peak at the G–band is attributed to graphene–like carbon. These results clearly indicated the formation of CN x layer on the surface of PRL(1)–Al2O3. Additionally, there are several kinds of N–species on the PRL(1)–Al2O3 sample as confirmed by the XPS results in Fig. 5, which was assigned to pyridinic–N, pyrrolic–N, graphitic–N and N oxides (Scheme S1), respectively [51]. Thus, the carbon nitride (CN x ) was formed by the modification of PRL. Moreover, there is a new Ru–N species besides pyridine–N, pyrrole–N, graphite–N and N–oxide [52,53], indicating Ru is modified with CN x on Al2O3. As observed in Fig. 6 and Fig. S3 , with the increase of PRL/Ru from 0 to 1, the binding energy of Ru 3d5/2 for Ru0 increased from 280.0 to 280.7 eV, while it did not increase further at PRL/Ru > 1, indicating that Ru0 in Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 was more positively charged than Ru/Al2O3, probably due to the electron transfer from Ru to CN x . Which is consistent to the formation of new Ru–N species confirmed from N 1 s XPS spectra. In addition, the ratio of Ru0/Ru4+ decreased from 1.57 to ∼1.1 with the addition of PRL, but changed slightly with increasing the content of PRL (Table S3). Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 catalysts were probed by powder X–ray diffraction (XRD) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). All the Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 catalysts showed broad diffraction around 20 ° corresponding to the (0 0 2) plane of graphite, which proved the existence of carbon species again ( Fig. 7). While no Ru related diffractions showed on Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3, but obvious metallic Ru diffraction presented on the Ru/Al2O3, suggesting that the formation of CN x species could promote Ru particle dispersion on the surface of PRL(x)–Al2O3, which was also demonstrated by TEM images ( Fig. 8). Ru was highly dispersed on the Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 samples with Ru particles as small as 0.8–1.2 nm. However, the Ru particle was much larger on Ru/Al2O3 with an average size of 2.7 nm in a wide distribution of 1–6 nm (Fig. 8 a). The similar results were also found by Jagadeesh et al. that N–containing species promoted Co nanoparticle dispersion and reduced its particle significantly [54]. It was also reported recently that Ru could be dispersed with single atom on CN–containing Nb2O5 [55]. What’s more, the Ru metal dispersion was evaluated further by CO adsorption in a pulse mode. The amount of CO adsorption over Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 catalysts (> 4.23 cm3/g) was much larger than that on the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst (2.97 cm3/g). The surface area and the pore volume of catalysts changed slightly with increasing the ratio of PRL/Ru, but decreased significantly with its further increasing to 4, which may be caused by the formation of too much carbon nitride and the blockage of the pore of Al2O3 (Table S3). With decreasing of Ru particle size, the dehydrogenation active sites (the Ru0 species at the interface of Ru nanoparticle and support) increased, so the activity of Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 is much higher than Ru/Al2O3. Importantly, primary amine tends to form on smaller metal particles due to the structure–sensitivity of oligomerization [23], which can explain the results of the higher selectivity to HMDA on Ru/PRL(1)/Al2O3 than that on Ru/Al2O3. In the control experiments, both Ru/PRL(0.5)–Al2O3 and 1 wt% Ru/Al2O3 have similar Ru particle in size around 1.2–1.3 nm (Fig. S4), but the Ru/Al2O3 showed much poorer activity and a relative lower selectivity compared with Ru/PRL(0.5)–Al2O3 (Table S4), indicating the positive effects of PRL modification again. As for Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3, Ru/PRL(2)–Al2O3 and Ru/PRL(4)–Al2O3 catalysts have the similar Ru particle in size, the differences in their catalytic performances should come from other factors such as electronic state of active Ru species and the acidity/basicity etc. The electronic property of Ru particles on different catalysts of Ru/Al2O3, Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3 and Ru/PRL(2)–Al2O3 was also discussed by in situ CO–DRIFT spectra ( Fig. 9). There are three adsorption bands at 2139, 2073 and 2007 cm–1 to present on the Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3 and Ru/PRL(2)–Al2O3 catalysts, which is attributed to multiple CO adsorbed on RuO x , linear CO adsorbed on RuO x and metallic Ru0, respectively [56]. For Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3 and Ru/PRL(2)–Al2O3, the latter two bands presented a blue shift, indicating a decrease in the electron density of metallic Ru compared with that in Ru/Al2O3, which is consistent with the XPS results. It certified again that the Ru species was modified by the surface CN x by the H2–TPR results (Fig. S5). There is only one kind of Ru species on the Al2O3 (170 °C), while a new kind of Ru species appeared on the surface of CN x modified PRL(2)–Al2O3 support, which located on the interface of Al2O3 and CN x (110 °C). The reduction peak presented above 400 °C was ascribed to the decomposition of CN x species in H2 atmosphere. Thus, the results demonstrated the stronger interaction existed between Ru and CN x on the surface of PRL(x)–Al2O3. The acidity and alkalinity were detected by NH3–TPD and CO2–TPD, respectively. In terms of NH3–TPD ( Fig. 10 a), all the catalysts showed weak acid sites with the desorption peak at around 150 °C. But the Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 catalysts possessed medium acid sites (desorption at about 280 °C) and strong acid sites (desorption around 350–700 °C) which increased with the ratio of PRL/Ru from 0 to 4, indicating the medium and strong acid sites should come from pyrrole–N species of CN x . The similar results were also found for the basic sites regarding CO2–TPD (Fig. 10 b), that the stronger basic sites increased with increasing ratio of PRL/Ru, it comes from pyridine–N species of CN x . 3.3 Relationship between structure and catalytic performances The amination of aliphatic alcohols to primary amines usually follows a dehydroamination pathway: dehydrogenation of CH–OH to –CO (step I), amination of –CO to –HC=NH (step II), and hydrogenation of –HC=NH to –CH2–NH2 (step III) [19,29]. Herein, step I is the rate–determining step due to the conversion of HDO and AHO is slow. A possible catalytic mechanism was proposed for the reductive amination of HDO on the surface of Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3 catalyst ( Scheme 3): (1) On the one hand, an alcohol was adsorbed on a Lewis acid (Alδ+)–base (Al–Oδ–) pair site to yield an alkoxide on the Alδ+ site and a proton on the Al–Oδ– site; On the other hand, an alcohol is adsorbed on a Brönsted acid (pyrrole–NH)–base (pyridine–N) pair site of CN x to yield an alkoxide on the pyrrole–N site and a proton on the pyridine–N site, (2) the alkoxide at the interface between Ru nanoparticle and Al2O3 or CN x undergoes hydride abstraction to form Ru–H and aldehyde, (3) the condensation of aldehyde with NH3 can proceed to form imine without catalyst, then the Ru–H species undergoes protolysis by a neighboring proton on the Al–OHδ+ site or the pyridine–NHδ+ site to hydrogenate the imine, accompanied by regeneration of the Ru0 site, acidic Alδ+, basic Al–Oδ– site, pyrrole–N sites. Similarly, the other hydroxyl group of HDO goes through the same pathway to produce the target product of HMDA. With increasing of PRL/Ru ratio, the Ru particle size decreased initially, then changed very little, while the amount of acidic and basic sites increased. With Ru particle size decreasing, the amount of the Ru0 species at the interface of Ru particle and support increased. The formation of CN x leads to the presence of Brönsted acid (pyrrole–NH)–base (pyridine–N) pair site. Thus, the synergistic effect of Ru0 and acid-base pairs promoted the dehydrogenation, and the conversion rate of –OH increased with increasing PRL/Ru ratio. The similar results were previously reported for dehydrogenation of alcohol in the reductive amination of propanol over hydroxyapatite supported Ni catalyst and furfuryl alcohol over hydrotalcite-derived nickel catalysts [19,31]. It was reported that HMDA can be easily converted into HMI, dimers and trimers, but HMI is converted mainly to dimers and trimers, but difficult to HMDA [34]. It was reported at high conversion (>90%) and low concentration of alcohol, the amine self–coupling is preferred to occur [22–24]. Herein, the relationship between selectivity and catalyst structure was discussed. (1) The Ru particle was smaller on the Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 compared to Ru/Al2O3 due to the modification of CN x . As secondary imine is more bulky than primary imine, its adsorption and hydrogenation over the smaller Ru nanoparticle might be limited in comparison with the cases on the larger ones ( Scheme 4) [22,23]. After modified by CN x formed from PRL, Ru dispersion was improved to form smaller Ru particle in size, thus the hydrogenation of secondary imine was inhibited, and secondary imine can be reversibly converted to primary imine and amine, so the selectivity to HMDA increased. (2) The acidity and basicity increased as the modification with CN x as increasing of PRL/Ru on the surface of Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 catalysts, it should be noted that the strong acid sites are active for self–coupling of primary amine [19,57]. The dehydrogenation of an amino group of HMDA to form 6-amino-1-hexamethyleneimine, and the dehydrogenation and amination of AHO to form 6-amino-1-hexamethyleneimine, and the intramolecular coupling of 6-amino-1-hexamethyleneimine and hydrogenation to form HMI could be accelerated by enhancing surface acid strength. When the acid strength was high, the intermolecular coupling was also accelerated. (3) The Ru particles with positive charge make the adsorption and activation of the electron–rich primary imine much easier. The electron deficient Ru may be beneficial for the formation of primary amines. With increasing PRL/Ru, the Ru particle size decreased initially and then changed a little, the degree of electron deficiency of Ru increased first and then unchanged, while the amount of acidic and basic sites increased monotonously. As a result, the selectivity to HMDA first increased and then decreased, the selectivity to HMI increased with PRL/Ru increasing. The selectivity to HMDA reached the maximum value at PRL/Ru of 1. 3.4 Stability of catalyst The reusability of Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3 catalyst was examined ( Fig. 11). After each reaction run, the catalyst was washed with ethanol, tert–butanol and centrifuged for several times, then was used again in the next run without other treatments. The Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3 catalyst could maintain a yield of HMDA above 50% during the first three cycles. The Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3 catalyst stability was significantly improved by PRL modificationby comparison to Ru/Al2O3 which presented significant decrease in the second run (Fig. S6). The Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3 catalyst showed no change in Ru particle size after four cycles as confirmed by TEM (Fig. 8 f), and the leaching of Ru was not detected either, but an obvious carbon deposit and/or Al(OH)3 were formed according to the results of TGA and XRD (Figs. S7 and S8). Thus, the carbon deposition and the change in Al2O3 structure should be the factors responsible for the decrease in activity. 4 Conclusions The important diamine of HMDA was synthesized by a green route via reductive amination of HDO over a kind of Ru/PRL–Al2O3 catalyst. On the surface of Ru/PRL–Al2O3 catalyst, CN x species was formed under the thermal treatment. The CN x presented superior function to anchor and disperse Ru nanoparticles, provided new and more acid–base pairs and induced the Ru species to be more electron deficient, which are responsible for the improved catalytic performances and stability of Ru/PRL–Al2O3 catalyst. HMDA was produced with a yield of 54%, which is superior to all the results over heterogeneous catalysts reported. Moreover, an additional important chemical of HMI was also produced with HMDA together, the total yield of HMDA and HMI was as high as 80% on the Ru/PRL(1)–Al2O3. The present catalysis system as a green route is of great potential to replace the traditional method of HMDA production. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of 1,6–hexamethylenediamine via the reductive amination of 1,6–hexanediol is a fascinating green process and a challenging topic. We developed a kind of Ru/PRL(x)–Al2O3 catalyst for the reductive amination of 1,6–hexanediol, the active Ru species was highly dispersed and anchored by the CNx species formed from 1,10-phenanthroline (PRL). The Ru particle dispersion, electronic interaction, and acid–basic property as well as the catalytic mechanism and the rate determining step were discussed in detail. The new and more acid–base pairs formed, and the electron deficient Ru species and smaller nanoparticles are responsible for the improved catalytic performances of Ru/PRL–Al2O3 catalyst. The yield of 1,6–hexamethylenediamine could reach to 54%, which is the best results reported up to now. The present catalytic process is of great potential for industrial application as it is a green process compared to the traditional method for 1,6–hexamethylenediamine production.
coredata.dc:title: Reductive amination of 1,6-hexanediol with a modified Ru/Al2O3 catalyst
